Description: A complete, brown, rectangular, leather amulet (higab), neatly stitched. The case was constructed by folding a leather strip across the bottom, sewing the two sides, folding the top over and sewing it closed. Space was left at the top fold for a string or cord to be inserted so that the amulet could be tied to the upper arm or around the neck. An apotropaic Arabic text written in black ink on paper was tightly folded several times to form a small square which was placed within the leather case. The text was wrapped in several layers of cotton fabric. The text consists of a magical rhombus of nine cells placed near the beginning of the inscription and 35 lines of Koranic and magical passages.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Kulubnarti, 21-S-40 House 5 Room 3 Above floor
Bibliographic references: Adams & Adams 1998 / Kulubnarti II, The Artifactual Remains (p.84-85, 89, 128, 129, fig. 11.2, pl. 10.2E,e)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2006, London, BM, Gallery 61, 'Kulubnarti' 2007 9 Mar-3 Sept, Belgium, Musee Royal de Mariemont, 'Pharaons noirs Sur la Piste des Quarante Jours' 2015, 19th June - 5th Sept. Wrexham County Borough Museum. Egyptian Written Culture. 2016 12 Mar-8 May, Carlisle, Tullie House, Writing for Eternity 2016 20 May-4 Sept, The Salisbury Museum, Writing for Eternity 2016 16 Sept-10 Jan 2017, Abergavenny Museum, Writing for Eternity 2017 21 Jan-21 May, Museum of Hartlepool, Writing for Eternity
Condition: Complete. Case was opened in the University of Kentucky lab to reveal the text within.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Dr William Yewdale Adams
Donated by: W S Webb Museum of Anthropology (University of Kentucky)
